Lucy

messages.msgSnippet: I got two from Johanna, too! But they had bad file data! Oh, poor Johanna! I hope people don t think she s sending them nude pictures of herself! The really
messages.messageBody:
I got two from Johanna, too! But they had bad file
data! Oh, poor Johanna! I hope people don't think
she's sending them nude pictures of herself! The
really weird thing about the ones from Johanna is that
what *I* said was quoted, then it said, "Take a look
at this link! Johanna" I replied saying they were
corrupt file data. Did anyone see that reply from me
or did it go somewhere else? Juli

> I got two like this from Johanna titled fun.pif and

> unknown, and seemed to be in Dos.

> Nanci K.

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] What exactly/attachments?
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 4/18/01 6:09:34 PM Pacific Daylight Time, vlos@oz.net writes:  Take a look to the attachment.  I got this as a private email from
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 4/18/01 6:09:34 PM Pacific Daylight Time, vlos@...
writes:

<< > Take a look to the attachment. >>

I got this as a private email from Valerie Stewart and have no idea what
it is. It was in response to my post answering what I do. I got another one
just like it in response to my post about violence in movies. I would like
to ask why we get so much email now with some form of attachments, most the
kind that don't need to be downloaded, but this was a regular download type.
I don't know that much about that even though I've had a computer for 2 1/2
yrs now. I just know that everytime I go to open any of the attachment
types, AOL has a warning first and I know that that's how the computer
viruses get into your computer so I'm wondering why there's so much of it
now. I don't mean this as an argument; just truly wondering is there
something about posting this way that makes it easier or what?
Also, I don't want to download this attachment from Valerie unless she
can tell me what it is. Thanks...

Lucy
